textRegions.text:
Dradis
[drey-dis]
noun
 
1) A highly sensitive detection, identification, navigation and tracking system, analogous in function to radar, used aboard the Colonial spacecraft in Battlestar Galactica.

2) A site for employers on Indeed to post jobs and track applicants. Extremely easy to use and efficient in increasing applications. Available at employers.indeed.com.
Wait, what did I actually work on?

I worked on many different new features and improvements to the Employers website. I will show you five: confirmation alerts, candidate notes, table sorting, candidate search highlighting, and text quality meter.
Orange arrows are server-side interactions, requesting and posting data from and to the server.
Green arrows are client-side interactions, moving data around the page without hitting the server.
This represents any action that happens right in front of your eyes. Users can see it.
This represents any action that happens behind the scenes. There’s stuff moving around that users can’t see.
Any text above, below, next to, over, behind, and through the log arrow is data that is being transferred along the interaction.
After a job is edited or posted, an alert is shown to confirm that the transaction was successful.
The confirmation also links to resumes that match the job title and location.
Keep track of the job title and location.
Store the job data in the database.
Post or edit a new job.
Populate alerts data with confirmation and resume search link.
Allows employers to add notes for each candidate on the same page as their cover letter and resume.
Useful for employers to write out their thoughts about a candidate before and after an interview.
Push the note to the database.
Submit a new note on a candidate page.
Check if the note is successfully stored.
On the tables that show the posted jobs or applied candidates, the user can sort by column.
If there are many entries, pagination is required, enabling server-side sorting.
If there are few entries, for optimization, client-side sorting is used instead.
Client-side sorting if only one page.
Previously it only searched through fields and cover letter, now it also searches through resumes.
The results show snippets and highlights of where the query is matched.
Use query to search for candidate IDs in elasticsearch.
Use candidate IDs to get candidate data from the database.
Display candidates with snippets and highlights.
Highlight where the query shows up in the candidate fields.
Rates the quality of an input and gives suggestions based on the input.
Especially useful for job titles, giving tips that will help the job’s search rankings.
Reusable on any form element with text input.
Start changing job title on the post/edit job form.
Check the text against specified rules for the input.
Display the suggestions depending on whether which rules the input passes/fails.

list of
input rules
and suggestions
Set the rules and suggestions for each input.

Robust front-end interaction using the powerful Javascript library, Google Closure.
Not to dislike Java. I thought I would never touch it again, but 50% of my output was Java.
How to use intuitive HTML Soy templates.
Order of operations when stuck: Google → documentation → Google → mentor
Writing code that will not anger the next person reading it. That means extensive documentation.
Writing reusable code. That means abstraction. And extensive documentation.

For getting me fat every day with catered lunches. For a packed movie theatre to watch Prometheus, 60mph go-carts, horseback riding, and a reason to legitimately say “I’m on a boat!” For entrusting me with impactful, meaningful work. For surrounding me with awesome interns and co-workers. For a great summer.
